JuUnJf5gPpPOdvPh5IUEpw.text: Read lots of good things about this, and I was staying at the Cafe Royal Hotel across the street (on Regent) so I decided to give it a try. Their version of a caesar salad was average at best. The real disappointment was their 650g rib steak.  I've had more tender chuck steaks (Grade A) with okay flavour but nothing to write home over especially for nearly 60 pounds.  The new potatoes were fine and the toffee pudding was nice (again nothing special).  I made the mistake (mine) of picking a wine from the Rhone Valley that tasted more like vinegar (too much tannic acid) - though admittedly I'm not a wine connoisseur.   Sorry, need to look for another steak house in London!!!!

1LUaSPULvE5AIIY8WMBBpg.text: I know this place is in a tourist area but it's great came here just for the Sunday roast made reservations a head of time.  I like the interior was greeted and seated quickly the service was great. The roast was fantastic nice cut of meat good portion and the gravy was so good I couldn't stop pouring it on. Lots of vegetables and Yorkshire pudding made it complete.  This place was a recommendation from a friend and they said a comparable Sunday roast elsewhere would cost more so I was quite pleased.

IzXNnY54JrU7WIABR0UV9Q.text: Sunday roast. I can manage without mushy peas. I'd be fine without Scotch eggs. But, Sunday roast? This is one British food tradition that America should fully embrace. Our Sunday roast at Hawksmoor was flawless. The gorgeous furnishings, the helpful service, the amazing food, and the excellent wine were all impeccable. We started with the half Dartmouth lobster and Doddington caesar salad, followed by heaping plates of Sunday roast accompanied by a perfectly balanced shiraz, then a sticky toffee pudding to share. The waiter, who was affable and helpful throughout, even arranged to extend our reservation so that we could finish our dessert without rushing. So much happiness. The lobster was cooked perfectly, accompanied by a nicely balanced herb butter, and absolutely delicious. The caesar came with anchovies, so I carefully ate around those, but the broad romaine leaves were nicely dressed, with a generous amount of Parmesan. The main attraction was the roast beef. It was served with duck fat roast potatoes, Yorkshire pudding, carrots, greens, and a lovely little pot of bone marrow & onion gravy. I don't usually like gravy, but even I couldn't deny the yumminess. And the sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream was just the right amount of sweet to share. For the price, the Sunday roast is a terrific value and the ideal way to enjoy one of London's best steakhouses. Make a reservation the next time you're in town. And bring me back some!

qj7-Nu077otismLxcWCowA.text: Great steak. Cooked just the way you want it and seasoned very well. The lobster comes with a butter sauce that becomes addicting. The mushrooms were average but the scallops were amazing. Reservation recommended.

G4xmx3X7aNeCzBmaBXOKvQ.text: I've constantly heard about how Hawksmoor is the best place in London to get a proper steak, so it has been on my list for a while now. This particular Piccadilly branch also specializes in seafood, but my friend and I stuck to the restaurant's heart and soul - red meat. We decided to ball out, ordering 800g of their chateaubriand. I couldn't believe all they used to season it was salt since it was so flavorful! Our really cool Polish waiter said that their mac 'n' cheese here is bomb as well, but that will have to wait till next time.

6KD9mXXHLpFxP69bdKsCLQ.text: The toffee sticky pudding was the best. I mean it. If you can go for anything, do that. Go for dessert!!

ss5BWUnHT_BkM1KvTQHJhA.text: Not sure how this place has such glowing reviews. Dined here while visiting in London. Possible we went on an off night because the restaurant was nearly empty. We ordered the scallops which were divine, along with 2 sirloin steaks and some sides. The steak however was abysmal. It was a very cheap cut of meat, and extremely chewy. Not at all what we would have expected from a steakhouse or any restaurant. We actually left the steak at the table and filled up on the bread and sides that we had ordered Very disappointing, especially at this price point. I wish we had picked somewhere else to dine at during our one night in London. Too bad.

kpBdfJlScbKFTS_4YsDWrg.text: Came in for dinner before seeing Les Miserable. The food is reasonably priced considering the quality and quantity that you good. The steaks were cooked perfectly and they were huge, I liked that we got to choose the size of our steaks. The sides were all delicious, especially the potatoes and mac n cheese! The drinks here are refreshing and strong and the service is some of the best we had in London!

WTP-_u77savmmcGWRviB5w.text: One of my favorite places that I tried while in London this past trip.  The food was exquisite... and the drink menu was super creative. Server was great - let me try some of the different wines before i had to commit to one. The steak had this cheesy hollandaise sauce that was.... magical. I promptly dipped everything I had in it -- so I added some to my creamed spinach (made it better), dipped my triple fried french fries (were were excellent) in it, and put it on my steak. And I'm going to figure out how to make it at home for steaks in the future.

RT6WKUBhyu4hy_X1l7d9Wg.text: This is a tough one. It has so many plusses, however, the negatives wouldn't put this on the list of places I'd be running back to. Still, it's hard to be too tough.It's a gorgeous facility. The service is really first rate. Our server was professional, and knew the exact level of formality/informality for the wife and I. Cocktails were well made. My only issue probably doesn't hold sway for most people coming here. I'm completely spoiled with the caliber of dry aged prime grade beef I can get locally here in the Western US where I live. I appreciate grass fed, and older, heritage beef, but it's not my love.That said, outside of a personal preference, there's nothing not to love here.

zbh3hlED3iuNvbajIaa17g.text: On vacation in England and spending a night in London. Compared a few steakhouses and settled on Hawksmoor. Did not disappoint, steak was fantastic, sides were delicious. The hops and glory cocktail was unique, sour, bitter, sweet and refreshing somehow all at the same time and be sticky toffee pudding lived up to the reviews.

doeW6U0FOqdChXayJn4dDA.text: Excellent steak restaurant that would make any American feel at home. In all seriousness, plenty of choice meat cuts and veggie selections. You will find a fair collection of crazy beers, single malt options and a fun list of Kentucky bourbons. So if you are jeeving for an awesome meat selection, Hawksmoor is your pick. tJYLjuyMRLWzcr7H_n74MA.text: Came on my own to see how it was. Firstly the entire reason I came here was the lobster mac and cheese and they don't have it right now. I wouldn't mind if I got the menu off yelp but it was on their main website where some restaurants in London don't do it and this one does (the reason I walked further to this one). I did bring this up with the server and hostess and they said the online menu is always wrong to which I explained but if he other restaurants have variations of the menu then why doesn't there's...Secondly I then order a number of sides I had eyed out as back up included buttered greens to then be told they don't do it anymore either, so again bad online menu and bad indoor menu.Thirdly I ordered a stout beer on arrival and it took over 20 minutes to get to me (only because I reminded my server), possible due to being on my own byt they weren't busy and there was no reason for stuff like that to be delayed. Whenever I used to work to restaurants I used to worry about 'secret shoppers' and if I was one right now then massive fail...Food was nice so that saved it being a two instead of a three but for the effort of getting there and service not enough...try harder next time.

z_kGdN2wE--uBSHvx4cbsw.text: We did not have a reservation on a Friday night and was still able to get a table in 30 minutes.  Bravo!  Great food and service.  Must try if you're around Piccadilly Circus and in the mood for a steak.

K-tGRuDw3Uiflp-SrdAWMw.text: Fantastic service, great London vibe (very open so noise levels are a little high) people dressed nicely, and the food - WOW!! I'm a massive steak lover and this filet was definitely one of the BEST I've had around the world. My man had the Monk fish and said it was delicious!! Salads were large, sides were perfect. Mac & Cheese = yum!! You do have to pay for bread and butter (a different tactic than in the states) but worth the $. I would absolutely recommend this restaurant to anyone!

NcR4GpjfGTkewRwgJZbKog.text: We were there for my birthday and had a fantastic time. Great food, drinks and service. Check this place out. The bar has a fantastic selection of whiskey. I can't wait to go back.

tHgXAs5V0f1auyN5S5Gkbw.text: Excellent steakhouse with a hip, but appropriately stodgy English aristocrat vibe. Very cool Art Deco architecture.I won't say this is the best steak place I've ever been to, but it is absolutely in the top 3. We shared a Potted Beef and bacon with Yorkshires to start. Yes, it was amazing as it sounds. Then we went with fillets and rib eyes for the main, which were perfectly done. Had mushrooms, English greens and chips as sides - all were fantastic. Finished it off with a Sticky Toffee Pudding with clotted cream, which is one of the better desserts I've had in a while. Just an excellent meal all around.

sml0fv5RX-UhFVVhvwk_vQ.text: The food was great, but the service was pretty awful. The staff was, at most, friendly, but distracted, terse, and unattentive. Took 15 minutes for someone to take our drink order. For a restaurant so highly priced, I expected better service. I read reviews that said "good food, bad service," but figured that might be a lone occurrence. This is not the case, so plan accordingly.

azWNtfV4g2_eE-7hpc1DZw.text: This is some serious meat folks. This Hawksmoor is apparently also a seafood restaurant but none of us ordered a fish main. Given it was my first time to a Hawksmoor restaurant, I was aching to try their steak.Thanks to Linzi who manage to procure a reservation for the "extended soft opening", six of us found our way to Hawksmoor Air Street late on a Sunday night. Very late. We got there early and had a few drinks; I had the Ginger Brew, the Dandy and the Garden Party. (At least I think those are the names... I hadn't eaten most of the day so I got quite drunk on them). They were all extremely tasty and quite pleasant. We started out in the bar area which was upstairs outside the dining area. Comfy seating and elegant surroundings made for a great drinking experience. The dining area is huge by the way. They showed us to our seats and it just kept going. I swear i thought we were never going to get there. The six of us decided to split six starters. For me, the best starters were the potted beef and bacon with Yorkshires and the pork belly ribs. They were both packed full of flavor, but I think the potted beef might have been slightly better (for my tastes). The bone marrow was also quite tasty, and the chicory salad was a nice crispy and green offset for all the meat and fish on the table. The friend Queenies were alright. The tartare sauce was great, but deep frying scallops isn't, in my opinion, the best way to showcase the taste of scallops. The mussels were terrible. I'm the only one who thought so, but for me, they were just way too fishy and didn't taste of anything else. I had three, and they were all overly fishy. No one else complained, so either I was incredibly unlucky, or my palate for fishiness is spectacular. However, there were enough of the other mains that I didn't feel bad about having one out of six that wasn't exactly to my tastes.For the main, I had the rib-eye steak and a half lobster (and more bone marrow which I scooped all over my meat). We split sides: two orders of chips, some sort of mashed potatoey thingy with cream and anchovies, macaroni and cheese, and a sweet potato. They were all really good, and those chips were fantastic. We also got all the sauces to try. The bone marrow gravy was heavenly (especially on the chips). I liked both the blue cheese and the anchovy Hollandaise sauces. The Bearnaise was lacking a bit in flavor from the others, but I enjoyed all the ones I tried. The steak was perfectly cooked and melted in my mouth. The lobster was okay. The tail was tasty and cooked well, but my giant claw was a bit salty and waterlogged.For dessert, I had the peanut butter shortbread with salted caramel ice cream. Yummo! It was like a warm peanut butter cookie with ice cream. The center had peanuts and other deliciousness in it, and I just ate it all up. I tried a bit of the sticky toffee which was quite rich and decadent, but the most decadent of all was the Jaffa cake. I had a bite, and I'm not sure how someone could eat the whole thing. No wonder Anna was handing it out left and right. It had that wow factor in your mouth, but it was huge and rich! Andrew got the salted caramel rolos, which were awesome, but I was expecting something to look like rolos, and not just like chocolate covered caramels.Anyway, everything was great! The service was spot on, the food was pretty fantastic (even if there were a few things that were off). I'm looking forward to going back to Hawksmoor again to have more of their delicious meat.So thanks again Linzi for getting the reservation (and giving it to Andrew), and thanks Andrew for inviting me along. If you like a big hunk of meat, the Hawksmoor is definitely the place to go for it.

rya93tmnibsGGC0MPI-sAg.text: This is the historic place where I got introduced to Yorkshire pudding and beef dripping fries. Meeting Yorkshire pudding felt rather like an encounter with a relative u don't want to get to know too much.However, I was deeply fond of the beef dripping fries. I mean, come on! BEEF DRIPPING FRIES! The name itself sounds like sex on a plate. We are bff now.Of course I not only had sides, I orderd the the roast beef. Apparently a must at this place. Order it pink, I usually order my meat medium rare, I don't know why I did not this time. The pink version really tastes like over the moon meaty and juice. It has a wonderful BBQ flavour. They have a cool cocktail menu, too bad I do not really indulge in cocktails at lunchtime but I would have loved to try loads of them ;)We also had "pudding" and we liked it. However, I do not remember what it was but it was small (thank god, we were stuffed!). Maybe rolos?I can't get over the fact that the sweet meal is called pudding. That's so funny. Being mainland Eurasian, for me a pudding is a creamy not too liquid dessert. But oooh, when I mentioned that to our British host at our table I feared he was less amused ;))

zSjurxrcta4sFKrAWTBkYA.text: Anna, our server, provided the best service i had in a resteraunt in a long time. The queenies were delicous as was the crab on toast. Had a  good ribeye with peppercorn sauce. The steak was thinner than what you would receive in the US but it did not lack in taste. My colleagues and I enjoyed the experience and i would recommend Hawksmoore to friends.

x5B2HBdzCF8OPGdCBQX2iA.text: First class from the moment you walk in, upstairs to the cocktail bar, drinks are superb, we stayed just for drinks be really enjoyed the atmosphere and top drawer drinks.

nMpZjwuNMNFMhNVOgXPOag.text: This is a top notch venue for a Sunday roast with excellent and efficient staff. The food was superb. Gorgeous dining room. Faultless

-imtTogLYOBfSzunJwpAzQ.text: I will go back again and again for the Full-Fat Old Fashioned...and the food is very good too!

JOCAu1U3-HuSU0xBj8H19Q.text: Excellent filet! A bit loud for my taste so don't go there expecting it to be quiet. Nice and fast service. Fairly expensive.

Y3mQ_xUtbUUw2HLd1Mj5fg.text: I'm an advocate of Hawksmoor but my last two visits have been disappointing. Both times I have had the fillet steak (medium rare) and it has been served cold with far too much salt, not great. Disappointing because I know they can do so much better.

6HJkPpnenqfx6oSTuhRwpg.text: Hawksmoor Air St. is the latest branch of the hugely popular,swanky steak hangouts, but the advantage is they do seafood and proper fancy seafood equalling the might of the steak. Off Regent St, so great for a glam night out with friends or for refuge after shopping. Also, there is a good sized bar to kick the night off and then be led into a never-ending majestic, art-deco, main dining hall (like a panoramic photo) . Lots of wood pannelling and plush,jaguar-green, leather upholstery (v gentleman's club). Now, the food in a word, sensational. Begin your feast with lightly battered, queenie scallops with tangy, lush tartar saucenever had scallops like this before. Then the big decision, seafood or steak or get both between 2 of you, which worked a treat (no food envy). Then, condiment heaven anchovy hollandaise (a creamy dip of loveliness) and bone marrow gravy (packed with strong, gravy flavours). Final hurdle is the dessert, all yummy and don't forget the salty caramel rolos, the perfect end to the perfect belly- busting meal. My favourite place at the moment. Beware book ahead, vvvv popular and not cheap, but so worth it. You're worth it! (monikasays.com )

vbvSi49NnZVQpHgT03ZmiQ.text: Best steak in London without a doubt. I've been to hawksmoor a couple of times now, and never been disappointed. Well worth a visit

o-nOTER3IwW-vO8HngAUsA.text: This restaurant was recommended by the concierge at our hotel, and we arrived for early dinner at 6:30 pm on a Monday night.  The restaurant was virtually empty when we got there, but within the hour it was half full.  The acoustics are so dreadful, when the restaurant gets busy you have to shout across the table to be heard -- and we had a corner booth at the very back, I can't imagine how loud it would be at a table in the center of the restaurant.  We ordered a prime rib for three expecting excellent beef, so we didn't order any of the sauces, and the beef was tasteless -- it just didn't have any flavor.  My guest ordered a Glenfiddich whiskey, but they were out of it so they gave her some other really expensive whiskey, which she said was fine but the shot was so meagre for the price, she felt it was very poor value for the money.  Service was fine until our meal was served, and then the waiters ignored us -- it took 10 minutes to get someone's attention to bring us the bill.  All in all, extremely disappointing -- especially given how much the meal cost.  Also the restaurant really has no atmosphere, it feels like an upscale Outback steak house with an overpriced menu.  Friends of mine have gone to the other two Hawksmoor restaurants and have had good experiences, and they say the ambience at the other restaurants is very nice.  Not so at this restaurant.

y19OdxpohFADGZGyqNZEnQ.text: It's way bigger than you'd imagine from the tiny doorway on Air.  It's a classy joint - feels very American steakhouse-y to me.  Nice art deco windows, big booths, dark paneling... Probably good for a work dinner. I wouldn't come on a Monday - you'll have limited seafood options (I know, I know - amateur move). Steaks were good, get the mac & cheese, triple cooked fries are always a yum, creamed spinach is tasty too (and this is coming from someone who normally doesn't like it). Sticky toffee pudding was good (standard) but not the best I've had. Great service - fun and friendly, highly attentive.

danNdNtquEYGpS4fc08J3w.text: Excellent. That's the only way I can describe Hawksmoor Air St. It's the new version of this Covent Garden British steakhouse which has now expanded to Liverpool St, the City and Regent St. The prices aren't cheap, but you leave feeling completely satisifed, and I can't fault any of the food, the cocktails, or their wine list.The staff work hard to make sure you have a good experience, from offering free ice water, to offering free starters when there was going to be a delay with the food. I've started saving up so I can visit again.

6n3uFX6OKytSaWwoRhleMw.text: I had the pleasure of visiting the bar upstairs and I was so impressed. We chose to get dessert our last day in London here, and the sticky toffee pudding did not disappoint. I have really enjoyed this pudding since trying it at a Gordon Ramsay restaurant in Las Vegas, and this one easily became my new favorite. The waiter we had also completely made the visit. He was incredibly sarcastic and perfect for our group, very good at reading the people he was serving. It was such an incredible visit were already talking about our next visit when we return to London.

BiBEw0CH05ELyJaLz00iJw.text: Yes, it's another 5 stars for Hawksmoor.They just keep doing it. First thing I noticed about this location is the LIGHT. Bright, with gorgeous windows, the light bounced off the reclaimed metal and polished wood. I've usually been to Hawksmoor  in the evening, and most of them are downstairs. Natural light with my porterhouse is a rare treat.The place is beautifully decorated. I'm a big fan of the teal leather and the industrial metal/wood combo which is a running theme at their restaurants. They have a bar area, but on this Sunday afternoon it was empty and we moved straight through to take our table.It was the soft opening, so our waiter wasn't up to speed on everything; names of cocktails, cuts etc, but hey, that's what soft openings are for - and we were getting 50% off food to numb the pain.The food - excellent as always. Their scallops might just be the best seafood I've ever had. Order them immediately. We shared porterhouse and prime-rib cuts between the four of us, which arrived cut and seasoned in heavy metal dishes. The steak was exceptionally tender and tasty. With Hawksmoor you really do know where you're spending your money. The standard is excellent. We opted for a range of sides including field mushrooms, creamed spinach, chips and greens. My favourite Hawksmoor side continues to be the mushrooms -juicy and served with a peppery season.Sharing is caring and so we selected a number of the desserts and grabbed a spoon each. We took one bite of their salted caramel rolos (probably the cheapest thing on the menu?) and instantly ordered more. We hadn't even made progress into the other desserts. We just knew we needed more of those rolos in our lives. Incredible. Other dessert highlights were the Ferrero Rocher sundae and the plum and blackberry pie.We had some very well made cocktails and a tasty bottle of red to accompany our meal. We couldn't have been happier.7I'll be back to pay 100% soon.

_gWjzEG-_I0kIuU8Y5sufQ.text: The girls & I wanted a good catch up with good food that won't break our banks. We decided to go to Hawksmoor as we've always wanted to try out their steak.We went for the express menu for a 3 course meal and the price (at £26) suits us. I had the Potted beef & bacon with Yorkshires which is a complete meal on its own. The Potted beef & bacon was delicious and moist. It was full of flavour! I just wished they had more gravy as the Yorkshire pudding was a bit over done. The rib-eye steak was cooked to perfection. We were all happy with our greens and chips. The Peanut butter shortbread with salted caramel ice-cream was absolutely divine! Because we went for the "express menu", I was hoping our customer services won't be an "express customer services". It was completely the opposite to what I expected. Excellent customer services. Smiles all around.

c0g9Yd-YgEoKgAmUcZVeJA.text: I had been looking forward to my first visit to a 'Hawksmoor' with some anticipation. It's touted as offering the best steaks in town and I would probably go along with that.The roast scallops and Belly ribs starters are definitely worth a go. The Chateaubriand (medium rare) was cooked perfectly and was as tasty as any steak I've experienced.The service however was a bit of a let down. Our waitress insisted on overselling the quantity of food that we ordered, somewhat surprising given her svelte figure and that of my two companions. As it was we left the last slice of steak as we were full to bursting!Anyway, the upshot is I would go back again, fully versed with the quantities I need to order, as the food quality was excellent, although given the prices it might only be for a special occasion.

5Mq0ekRagnDuJrVkkdjyAw.text: I was quite excited about the Hawksmoor but I have to say I left feeling unimpressed.Now I'm a pretty experienced chef so I know that I am more critical than the usual diner so instead of giving a long winded review I will break it down to where I thought they fell short.1. Firstly we waited over 30 mins for two cocktails on arrival, and they weren't busy, but in their defense  the wait staff acknowledged they had forgotten the order and we weren't charged for our beverages and at 9 quid a pop that was kinda cool, we honestly weren't overly bothered. But a mistake in any case.To be honest I actually wasn't impressed with the cocktails, so I was glad not to pay.2. We are a young couple that were obviously out to enjoy an intimate and romantic night and were to my horror  put in a terrible table position right in front of the bar, we were booked quite late so I'm sure we could have had a better table. I felt like I was being seated in sizzler....not the Hawksmoor.3. Once seated I noticed the decor (tables, floor, bar) look tired, scratched and worn out, the restaurant definitely didn't have a feel of being a hip vibrant stylish steakhouse.4. We decided to go for a three course meal package that was offered at a good price after 10pm, big mistake. The bill with wine and added sides was still reasonable high so please don't think that things went down hill because we chose the cheap option.5. The entrees were vastly different in size, my entreel was massive and my girlfriends entree might as well have been a canapé, plus my Yorkshire puddings were burnt, no bread was offered. Not impressed. 6. Next course was a 250g steak for myself and Fish for my girlfriend. My steak was under cooked, and nothing great, the "triple fried chips" tasted and looked liked old fries from McDonalds, the fried bone marrow was two whole roasted marrow bones cut in half that I would feed my dog.... the only thing that was enjoyed were the minted potatoes, my girlfriend enjoyed them....that says it all.&. Dessert was also unimpressive, very rich desserts with a tiny quenelle of ice cream and double cream on mine, badly portioned and nothing special. Pub food.The wine list also was average and over priced.So in closing...one word...rubbish...I hate giving bad reviews but to be honest I left thinking I would have had a similar experience at the local pub for half the price.On a positive note the service staff were all very friendly and accommodating.Sack the chef, do a bit of a refurbishment and maybe I might go back one day. Until then. Not a chance.

P2m-B1cPlsLLhTPD3a5YFw.text: Oh.  My.  God.  It's as if I died and went to heaven.  My entire experience here was exceptional.  The venue itself is tucked away on Air Street - away from the hustle and bustle of Piccadilly Circus.  The ambiance was a sexy chic - sophisticated and classy.  The wait staff was attentive and made recommendations, some of which they guaranteed satisfaction and if there was any problem, they'd send the dish or drink back without any questions.  The strawberry signature cocktail was quite tasty, but I do recommend a good Malbec with the steak.  And if you enjoy a juicy filet mignon, just order one without even giving it a second thought - this was the best filet I've had in my life.  It was thick, juicy and succulent - I couldn't imagine a more perfect slab of red meat.  I didn't even order a sauce because it didn't need it.  Everyone raves about the chips and, while the chips were quite good, the macaroni and cheese was my favorite side dish (and I'm American and therefore a harsh critic on the British spin of Mac and cheese!).  Then, to top it off, the peanut shortbread is the perfect, delectable ending to a mouthwatering meal.  Do not come here on a diet nor a full stomach, because you will want to indulge, and indulge you should.  I am absolutely coming back here again - no ifs, ands nor buts.  This has now become my favorite restaurant in London.  Gaucho - watch your back.  You've got nothing on Hawksmoor.

WV_hMv0jj47obeZ1yS4iVA.text: Quite simply the best steak in London. This is my favourite branch, as it offers several fish options for non steak eaters and is the perfect setting for either a special occasion with your other half or a group dinner with friends.

XHGdYU1ibz6sLwSxmSjStA.text: Just out of eyeshot of tourist ground-zero sits an art deco haven of meat. If you've been following the reviews this far, you'll probably be all like, ok:Steak, check. Booze, check. Really central, check. So I won't waste your time. I will say though, the lobster cocktail misses the mark so you're probably better off without it and let's be real, if your bill is averaging £100 per person with wine, the chocolate rolos for dessert should just come with the bill. Everything else is going to put you in a delicious food coma that you'll be making payments on for a while. While you're at it, get the full fat old fashioned, you clearly deserve it if you're having a gluttonous night out. Is this something people say YOLO after? I've never understood that, but it might apply here.

ZOf-qWNQrllIs8BiLG9Qvg.text: This restaurant is really a favorite in London! I usually like going for the express menu. I was there the other night and had the pork starter (which was very flavorful), rump steak (cooked to perfection) and the peanut butter shortbread. You must try the peanut butter shortbread, it is very yummy!

C5qQ2An7B5nqaaLZu72MZQ.text: I wanted desperately for this to be a five star meal and has such high expectations I guess I was bound to be disappointed. Don't get me wrong, we had a fantastic meal, but some little things were a little off, which I wasn't expecting. Let's start with the good stuff: obviously, the meat. It's incredible. The steaks are cooked to perfection and taste like cow. The triple fried chips are also spectacular. But really, the star of the meal for me was the stilton hollandaise. I could BATHE in it. I actually ended up eating it on its own off the plate because I just couldn't get enough - but it works best, obviously, as an accompaniment to the beef. The desserts were also excellent - I had the peanut shortbread because salted caramel ice cream will make me order anything... my husband had the baked alaska which for my taste was too passion fruity and tangy, but he loved it. Perfect meringue. We skipped starters, knowing that we were more tempted by the sides and that the steaks were big - this turned out to be a wise decision.  We had a steak each, off the 'always available' part of the menu: a bone in sirloin, and a rib-eye. If I go again, I'd ditch the sirloin though, rib-eye is the way forward. The place itself is like something out of Mad Men, you can imagine the after dinner cigar smoke curling up to the ceiling... and the windows are particularly beautiful. It does feel special. So, the little things that added up to that minus star:The dining room is spectacularly noisy: not great acoustics here. The cocktails we had, having stellar expectations, were pretty bland. I tried a garden party - it tasted like a weak aperol spritz - and the hawksmoor collins is nothing to write home about. Perhaps it's my fault - I just couldn't bring myself to try butter infused bourbon then eat half a kilo of beef, but I wish I had now. The spinach and garlic side dish although okay was in my view massively overpriced, and ditto the Jansson's Temptation which lacked the oomph we were hoping for and was a little grainy. Weirdly, although the space feels special - and this is something I would never normally comment on, but it jarred here - the staff are really dressed down. Like, jeans and trainers dressed down. I found that a bit... 'oh'. If I'm paying upwards of £75 a head for dinner, I like to get a bit dressed up, and so then found it a bit odd to feel overdressed because of the staff. They were all lovely and friendly though. Don't get me wrong, I will be back: knowing that a single portion of hollandaise is plenty for 2, the greens are a waste of time, and a dessert can be shared.... I can save enough cash to try that butter bourbon.

I4ko6S-2vte4gfuedOOgHw.text: Came here early on a Friday evening. Service here is very friendly and efficient from the get go, with lots of smiles. The restaurant and separate bar are upstairs which is spacious and attractively set up. The only criticism I have of Hawksmoor is that the restaurants are very dark. I would like to be able to read the menu without getting my flashlight out.In our party of four we tried the shrimp on toast starter, the smoked salmon and the crab. Everyone was very happy with their choice and the plates went back clean. Main courses were Dover sole, offered on or off the bone, fillet steak and sirloin. The fish was pronounced good, the steaks were perfectly cooked and well seasoned. For sides we had the beef dripping fries (overcooked), mash and gravy (gorgeous), lovely creamed spinach and mushrooms. We went the whole hog and had the honeycomb sundae and the salted caramel tart. They were both delicious, especially the latter, which was flawlessly balanced. The wine was excellent, as was the service throughout. A wonderful dining experience; can't wait to return.

n33uo9IxvHHQyexKi0I__w.text: Had dinner here on my first trip to London. They don't seat you until right at your reservation time so we sat by the bar to wait. Service was a little slow but I think many would find it beneficial to sit and chat and relax between courses. I just wanted to be out a little quicker to site see some more. The Caesar salad was bland. The rump was very good and required no sauce and apparently is one of the best tasting steaks here despite being the cheapest. My brother got a t-bone which he said was just ok. He said the side of mushrooms was very good and much better than his steak. He also got a side of lobster but they must've forgotten because he didn't get it until 15-20 minutes after the rest of our food despite asking for it to be brought out at the same time. I had the sticky toffee pudding for dessert since everyone seems to love it. I find it to be slightly too sweet but the clotted cream on top helps tone it down. Nice atmosphere. Seems like a good place for a romantic date. Can be a bit pricey depending on what you get especially since they also charge for things like sauce. But I honestly don't think the sauce is necessary with how the steak is cooked.

sA_mb2F9XIcmipRJ1vN-WQ.text: Went back and again had a great experience,  scallops and shrimp on toast for starters and this time I went for the monk fish main, seriously good cooking and the peanut butter shortbread dessert capped it off lovely... Star knocked off for an error with the order and confusion over bill BUT to their credit both situations handled brilliantly by waiting staff, will definitely be going back

GC2M2kWNE9cT-MHbJwUUQA.text: Where to start? I loved the art deco setting. The feel of the place is luxurious and grown-up without seeming pretentious. You could happily dress up to the nines and dine out here for a special occasion, as much as you could grab a causal mid-week dinner in your ripped jeans and converse. We tried one of their (really excellent) cocktails, but no more as we were conscious of over-spending, which believe me you can do in a heartbeat at this place! But that's not to say that I felt it was over-priced, far from it actually, when food is this good I'm happy to slurge. And that's why this place shines- the food, more specifically the steak, is just sooooo good. We had a couple of starters that were really decent but didn't exactly blow us away I have to say, but the t-bone we shared was INCREDIBLE. I don't know how it does it, but a smear of anchovy hollandaise completely took the meat to another level. a-mazing. The only very small downside was that the peppercorn sauce I ordered was quite thin which was a bit of a downer for me, but not enough to knock off a star. Loved it.

ItvQ5tHV9vKnPMrozftEyA.text: I had never been to this in any location and it is a very good British steakhouse.  Probably my go-to if that's the cuisine you want.The cocktails are nice; I had a Corpse Reviver #2 which was excellent.  For mains we had the 300g fillet, triple cooked chips and broccoli.  Those were all excellentWe had the salted caramel tart and the peanut butter shortbread for dessert.  I think the PB shortbread was much better but both were good.

suxrrTVu3WEeBo-lb09E2A.text: Great addition to the Hawksmoor family.Have made all the rounds except to this one, and well worth braving the Picadilly Circus chaos.Pros: Hawksmoor quality, Ginger Pig sourced meat. Sunday roast is a deal for just under £20 with all the trimmings and generously proportioned Yorkshire puds. Perfectly cooked steaks, and perfectly sliced Porterhouses. Art Deco and dark wood decor. They make iced tea. They make sticky toffee sundaes. Enough said.Plus even the lobsters and fish courses are solid, for those mates of yours that are not feeling red-meaty on a particular outting.Cons: I always think the sides are too small, until I start eating. Then I think, did I really need to order an 850g Porterhouse and five sides, including creamed spinach and dauphinoise??? Maternity trousers recommended for all (not just pregnant women).

qvJuu80sMkHKFYDtsyTFpw.text: Food is delicious! Best Sunday roast I've ever had even if the portion was massive. Steak and sides were cooked perfectly.

JDMr8m5YlKn9r67jYspObw.text: The steak was very good but I wasn't that impressed by the triple cooked chips (a bit dry), and I think at those prices it's outrageous that you pay separately for sides. Very expensive. Restaurant also incredibly loud, we spent the evening shouting across the table at each other to be heard (tables are quite wide). Not somewhere for a romantic meal, or a catch up with a friend - choose somewhere quieter...Not sure I'll be back for the restaurant, for that money I think you could have better overall experiences elsewhere in London. The cocktail lounge looks cool though, so would happily check that out before heading elsewhere for food
